## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.


```{r}

library(psych)
library(MASS)
library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)
library(rstatix)
library(car)

```
```{r}

tidyData <- read.csv("chemistry-data-tidy.csv")

```


```{r}

head(tidyData)

```

```{r}

str(tidyData)

```
Renaming columns so they're easier to write.
```{r}

tidyData<- tidyData %>% 
  rename(
   "NH4 (mg/kg)" = NH4..mg.kg.,
   "TON (mg/kg)" = TON..mg.kg.,
   "K (mg/kg)" = K..mg.kg.,
   "NO2 (mg/kg)" = NO2..mg.kg.,
   "NO3 (mg/kg)" = NO3..mg.kg.,
   "Conductivity (mV)" = Conductivity..mV.,
   "Moisture (%)" = Moisture....
  )

head(tidyData)


```

```{r}
tidyData$Weeks <- as.factor(tidyData$Weeks)

tidyData$Treatment <- as.factor(tidyData$Treatment)

```


Normality tests
```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$pH)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`Conductivity (mV)`)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`NO3 (mg/kg)`)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`NO2 (mg/kg)`)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`NH4 (mg/kg)`)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`TON (mg/kg)`)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(tidyData$`K (mg/kg)`)

```

```{r}

tidyData %>% 
  group_by(Treatment, Weeks) %>%
  get_summary_stats(type = "mean_sd")

```

```{r}

pH_aov <- aov(pH ~ Treatment + Weeks, data = tidyData)

```

```{r}

shapiro.test(pH_aov$residuals)

```
```{r}

TukeyHSD(pH_aov)
```

```{r}

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

hist(pH_aov$residuals)
qqPlot(pH_aov$residuals, id = FALSE)

```



```{r}

for(i in 3:7){

  column <- names(tidyData[i]) 

  avz <- aov(tidyData[,i] ~ Treatment + Weeks, data = tidyData) # Each ANOVA test iterating through each column of my dataframe
  tukey <- TukeyHSD(aov(tidyData[,i] ~ Treatment + Weeks, data = tidyData))

  result <- summary(avz) # summarize each ANOVA in a table

  print(column)
  print(result)
  print(tukey)
}


```




```{r}

for (i in 3:7){
  column <- names(tidyData[i])
  anova <- aov(tidyData[,i] ~ Treatment + Weeks, data = tidyData)
  tukey <- TukeyHSD(anova)
  
    print(column)
    print(setNames(tukey, column))

}

```
